poem:
Diplomatic Fray  

In the wreckage of words,  
a bar-room clash lingers—  
across oceans, tense pulses quake,  
as Starmer treads in shifting cobblestones,  
grasping at brittle threads,  
seeking—amidst suspicion—  
to stitch the ragged seams  
of nations, hearts weary  
under clouds of dissonant echoes.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "After the Trump-Zelenskyy spat, Starmer may not have many cards left to play on Ukraine As Keir Starmer surveys the wreckage of the US-Ukrainian relationship caused by the Oval Office bar-room fight, the UK prime minister is clearly intent on trying to repair the diplomatic damage, but it may be that the mood of mutual antagonism not just in the US, but in Europe, is too great. It is not as if Starmer, to use". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
